summary.seg: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.32 is a medical compendium, made partly of parchment (ff. 1-66) and partly of paper (ff. 67-173), and was produced in England in the second half of the 15th century. The paper comes from the same stock, except for the last two quires (ff. 151-173; see Part 2), which are of a visibly different consistency. A single scribe copied the larger part of the texts in a mixed hand with elements of Anglicana and Secretary scripts (see Part 1), however other hands' interventions can be observed in this section of the manuscript (notably, a change of hand occurs at f. 76r in the middle of the 'Tractatus de urinis'). Part 2 contains a witness of the Latin herbal known as Circa instans, copied by a scribe not involved in the compilation of the previous texts. It is thus likely that originally these two quires had been a separate booklet and were added to the rest of the book at a later date.

MS R.14.32 contains exclusively medical texts of different genres, from theoretical treatises to herbals and recipes, which are for the most part Middle English translations of Latin originals. Along with the vernacular writings, the manuscript includes a collection of thirteen medical recipes in Latin (ff. 140r-144r) and the aforementioned Circa instans (ff. 151r-168r). Many of the texts in MS R.14.32 were largely widespread in the late Middle Ages, however the forms in which they occur in this manuscript sometimes deviate from the textual tradition. For example, the herbal on ff. 1v-65r, which has been traditionally identified with a witness of the Middle English Agnus Castus is in fact an original compilation derived from the Agnus Castus, the Circa instans, and other sources still to be identified. Among the entries of the herbal some spaces have been left blank, probably to add other plants' descriptions or botanical drawings.

Under the rubric 'Tractatus de urinis' (ff. 67r-80v), various texts on urines have been joined together to form a cohesive unity, very similar to the texts found in London, British Library, MS Sloane 121 and London, British Library, MS Sloane 706. The 'Tractatus de urinis' is followed by a small compendium made of nine texts, recorded in MS Sloane 706 and Cambridge, Jesus College, MS Q.D.1 as well. The compendium begins with an abridged Middle English translation of the Letter of Ipocras merged with a dietary regimen (ff. 81r-82r), and continues with treatises on the body parts where ailments arise (ff. 82v-83r), the heartbeat (ff. 83r-85v), the leaves of sage (f. 85v), bloodletting (ff. 86r-88r), the influence of planets on men's complexions (ff. 88r-88v), the four humours (ff. 88v-89r), and on the number of bones, veins and teeth in human body (f. 89v), and finally the four-chapters version of the Middle English translation of John of Burgundy's treatise on the plague (ff. 90r-92r). Other texts include a treatise on the medical properties of distilled waters (ff. 93r-93v) and a fragmentary Middle English translation of the Circa instans (ff. 128r-129v). There are also excerpts from the Middle English version of Geoffrey of Vinsauf's commentary on Palladius, known as the Book of Trees and Wine (ff. 130r-130v), and relatedly from the Craft of Grafting by Nicolas Bollard (f. 131r), a herbal in verse (ff. 134v-139v and 144v-146v), and a verse treatise on rosemary (ff. 147r-148r).

The corpus of medieval medical recipes displayed in MS R.14.32 is substantial: there are 288 such texts in total, all but a few of which are gathered in thematically organized collections (for example, the receptarium known as The Alchemical Waters of Saint Giles on ff. 96r-99r) or arranged according to the traditional head-to-foot order. The others were included as standalone items, such as the recipe for a well-known oral anaesthetic known as 'dwale' on f. 92v, or added to blank spaces within or at the end of these by 15th- and 16th-century hands (see, for example, ff. 94r-95r, 103v, 117r, 119v, 124v, 148v, 168v-169r). Two charms are also included: one to staunch blood (f. 132r), crossed out by a later hand (probably of an early modern owner of the manuscript), and one 'Pro Spasmo' (f. 134r), written in a pale, faded shade of ink.

Little is known about the history of this compendium. The addition of recipes just mentioned, or supplementary entries to the Agnus Castus-derived herbal (e.g. on f. 36r), and other occasional miscellaneous annotations (ff. 92r, 169r-173v) are the only evidence of medieval use, and the manuscript contains no information as to the identity of its owners at that time. Further additions by sixteenth-century hands testify to its continued use in the early modern period and more specifically - given that most of these were remedies - a prolonged interest in medical practice. One of these, 'For the yellow jaundice', concludes with the inscription 'M[agister] R Arche a[nno] d[omi]ni 1548', which might be the name of the author of this addition (and others preceding it, which were written in a closely similar script) or the person from whom this particular recipe was obtained.

The lack of evidence of medieval ownership notwithstanding, MS R.14.32 is a fascinating example of what is often described as a 'leechbook', a compendium of both theoretical medical texts as well as recipes, which practitioners of the healing arts might have used as a reference and commonplace book during their practice. The use of a single paper stock (aside from the later addition), the adoption of consistent layouts in the presentation of the texts, and their apparently purposeful arrangement in a sequence starting with general topics and concluding with specific remedies, suggests that the book was conceived as a whole from the outset by its owner-compiler, with empty spaces left deliberately in order to accommodate further additions as new medical remedies became known.

Dr Laura Poggesi
Post-Doctoral Research Fellow
University of Florence

supportDesc.support: Folios 1-66b are parchment. Folios 67-173 are paper.

foliation.note: Numbering in brown ink or pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

The 15th- or 16th-century foliation sequence in the manuscript's first part was continued for the rest of the manuscript by a 19th- or 20th-century modern library hand. In this catalogue record, this foliation sequence is followed. [172a] is an unfoliated stub bearing text, which has been assigned a number for the puposes of this electronic record.
Numbering in brown ink in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

note.p: A 17th-century hand has added the following description of the manuscript in brown ink to the lower half of f. 1r: In this Volume are contained 1. An Herbal in an Alphabetical order .2. a Treatise of Urine .3. Receipts for Oyntments etcaetera.
Quire numbers in Roman numerals written in pencil in the outer lower corners of the first rectos of quires by a modern hand.

binding.p: (?)17th-century brown leather; the spine re-backed but featuring its original spine label of read leather with the gold-stamped inscription: An Herbal etc. MSS.
Binding height: 195 mm; width: 140 mm; depth: 40 mm.

acquisition.p: Perhaps bequeathed to Cambridge, Trinity College, by John Wilson (d. 1754) Wilson, John, d. 1754, Fellow of Trinity College, tutor, senior bursar, vicar of Over and Chesterton (see: James (1902), pp. 317-319). The College's current classmark (R.14.32) is inscribed in red pencil on the inside of the upper cover, in brown ink on f. 1r [2x]. The alpha-numerical elements are printed separately onto three paper labels pasted onto the spine. Its old classmark R.8.32 inscribed in brown ink on f. 1r (crossed out). Its ex libris, featuring an engraving of its heraldic arms, motto (Virtus Vera Nobilitas), and name Coll: Trin: Cantab:) by William Stephens, fl. c. 1740-c. 1760 (Stephens sculp.) pasted onto the inside of the upper cover. Smaller versions of the ex libris have been pasted in the lower margin of f. 5v and on f. 11v. Its library stamps on ff. 1r, 2r, 11v, 12r, 13r, 65r, 67r, 103v, 104r, 140r, 150v, 173r.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge: a descriptive catalogue, 3 (1902); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.32, ff. 1-150

msContents.textLang: Middle English (Essex dialectical features: see LALME LP 6300) and Latin

msItem.title: Three medical recipes
msItem.note: Partially legible due to water damage or wear.

msItem.title: Two entries on the herbs apium and anetum
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with an added Latin heading
msItem.rubric: domesticum siue ortolanum ouus semen selinum spernia dicitur [added by a different hand]
msItem.incipit: 1v [A]pium anyce merche or smallage the seed therof is of grettyst vertewe and than the rote and than the herbe and thu fynde apium be himself in medycines
msItem.explicit: 1v ley .iiij. or .v. drye fyges all nyght in the juse of anete and amorow put therto a lytyll wyn and seeth all this . clense it . and whan is colde yeue him therof to drynke
msItem.note: These entries apparently belong to the next item (Agnus Castus), which features further entries by on blank spaces.

msItem.title: Agnus Castus [Middle English translation]
msItem.rubric: 2r [H]ere begynnythe an herbale of namys and uertues of diuerse herbys aftyr letterys of the .a.b..c etcaetera
msItem.incipit: 65r [A]pium risus or herba scelerata or botranon is an herbe that men clepe cerfoyle or cheuerele this herbe hath smale leuys lyche to the lefe of homloke but this herbe is gode yn sauour and he hath a whyte flour and longe sede lych to an ote the uertw of this herbe is yf he be dronke with wyne he wyll make a man to make water
msItem.explicit: 65r with colde thinges to a kele in suryppys to ij pouds of sugrer ther schal be put j pound of water and though ther be more it is non harm but for the enduryng
msItem.note: The text begins with Apiium Risus and ends with Zucarium. Blank pages were left throughout, to which both the main scribe and later scribes have added entries for herbs at their respective alphabetical locations. Many of the added entries are in Latin.
Contains extracts from the Circa instans and features a text on the virtues of rosemary.

msItem.title: Verses from the Disticha Catonis (Book IV), preceded by a line from the Athanasian Creed
msItem.rubric: 22r Dicta familiaria sapientium iurorum
msItem.incipit: 22r quicumque vulte salvus esse necesse est in ut teneat fidem catholicam / Quum coniunx tibi sit nec, res, et fama laborat
msItem.explicit: 22r despice diuitias, si uis animo esse beatus / quas qui suspiciunt, mendicant semper auar
msItem.note: Added in a neat Italic script by a (?) 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Saying
msItem.incipit: 41v Off wordly goods be ne [...] grede he that nothinge kepethe
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added on an empty space between the original text by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Draft line (possibly from Job 9:29)
msItem.incipit: 52r that I am wickede
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added to the upper margin by the same 16th-century hand that copied the draft sentence on f. 43v and a shorter version of the poem from which this line originates (written underneath by a different 16th-century hand) on f. 140r.

msItem.title: Draft line
msItem.incipit: 54v ffeare gode and the kinge be lathe
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added to the upper margin by the same 16th-century hand that copied the draft sentence on f. 42r and a shorter version of the poem from which this line originates (written underneath by a different 16th-century hand) on f. 140r.

msItem.title: Moral poem
msItem.incipit: 54v Kinge ffeare gode and the belothe for to offend / take nothinge in hand but thinke one the end / desiare not to hau no more than thyn owne / fore thorne is not hadd but wheare sead is sowne
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added on an empty page by a 16th-century hand by the same hand that copied a shorter version of this poem on f. 140r..

A very similar poem is to be found in St Botolph's Church, Barford, Norfolk, where it has been painted on the medieval rood screen in Elizabethan times: Serve God in this Place / Be loth to offend / Take nothing in hand / But think on the end.

msItem.title: Charm for retrieving stolen goods via a dream-vision
msItem.incipit: 60v Nota: [Take] valerian and gadyr him on oure lady day the ASsumcyon erly in the mornyng and late him ley it vnder his hede whan he goth to bedd and sey v. pater noster .v. aues . and j crede and than require the same erbe to schew the wher thi gode is be cum . And thu schalt haue very knowlyche in this slepe with inn .iij nyghtes wher thi gode is. And if thu wylt gadyr him a nothir tyme of the yere thu must sey ouer him .ix gospelles of seynt John. etcaetera
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand to a blank page.

msItem.title: Tract on harnassing the magical and medicinal properties of vervain
msItem.rubric: 64r Virtutes veruene
msItem.incipit: 64r Si ponatur in aqua omnes pisses ibi congregabuntur. Item si ponatur sub feminam non habebit potestatem sedendi sit virgo. Item si quis biberit succum eius erit inuisibilis donec biberit aquam benedictam
msItem.explicit: 64r Item collige vervenam quando habet flores et non plena luna et dic pater noster .v. colligendo sic - Coniuro te vervenam per uirtutem domini nostri Jhesu Christi . et per ista nomina + elyon + heloy + adonay + et per anima nomina dei ut si te in ore meo habuero dum aliquem vel aliquam osculatus fuero vel eos tetigero facias obdire michi et quod fuit in potestate mea et omnes inimici mei . In nomie patris quesiui te In nomine filij inuenio te In nomine spiritus sancti colligo te . Amen
msItem.note: Added on an empty page by a 15th-century hand. The tract ends with an instruction for a charm to make someone obey you by keeping vervain in the mouth while kissing or touching them.

msItem.title: Treatise on uroscopy
msItem.rubric: 67r Tractatus de vrinis
msItem.incipit: 67r Eche vryne is clensinge of blode as it is properly schewyd of thinges singnyfycatyfe so that it be of the lyuer of the veynes of the reynes and of the bladder of other thinges
msItem.explicit: 80v And yf it be not so but scatered abowte þan yt toekeneþ grete wynde in þe woombe and in þe sydes
msItem.note:
This is a compilation of uroscoping tracts, including:
Cleansing of Blood on ff. 67r-67v [see Tavormina (2016), p. 33 (no. 3.3.1a)]
Twenty Colours by Digestion Groups on ff. 67v-68r [see Tavormina (2016), p. 30 (no. 3.1.1b)]
Urina Rufa on ff. 68r-69r [see Tavormina (2016), p. 32 (no. 3.2)]
The Twenty-Jordan Series with the so-called Karapos incipit on ff. 69r-70r [see Tavormina (2016), p. 17 (no. 1.1.2a)]
A version of Walter Agilon's The Craft of Urines that Tavormina (2016) categorizes as the Tractatus Magistri Bartholomei on ff. 70r-80v [see Tavormina (2016), p. 95 (no. 16.1)] .
Copied by two hands: Hand A, the main hand of the manuscript who copied most of the Middle English translation of the Agnus Castus, was responsible for ff. 67r-75v; Hand B copied ff. 76r-80v.

msItem.title: Letter of Ipocras
msItem.rubric: 81r [T]his book ypocras sente vnto kynge cesar that he desired of him and nowe I haue it made and I sende it vn to yowe and wete wele it is gode tresure kepe it wele as your lyfe ffor I haue made it for helpe and helthe of your body
msItem.incipit: 81r Euery man beste and foule hath .iiij. humours which ben humours of mannys body . that is to seye . oon is hote . Another is colde . the thrid moyste . the .iiij. dry.
msItem.explicit: 81r And vse hem be the morun and at even and thes thinges schull put awey the superfluyte of flewme and kepe the body in gode temper and in helthe
msItem.note: The Letter of Ipocras with the so-called Treasure prologue on f. 81r [see Tavormina (2016), p. 37 (no. 4.1.2b)].

msItem.title: Four Parts Where the Sicknesses of the Body Begin
msItem.rubric: 82v De .iiijor corporum vbi insurgunt
msItem.incipit: 82v These ben the .iiij. partys in which the sekenys of body begynnyth . that is to seye . in the hede . in the breste . in the wombe . and in the bledder
msItem.explicit: 83r And but he vse this medycen he schall the dropsye or the leuer chafed . or the intrales stoppid or elles the stone

msItem.title: Treatise on nine pulses
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with a Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 83r Antra tauri Pulsus primus Spira primus compleccionis Colericus significat Taurus
msItem.incipit: 83r-83v [F]or to knowe the desese of a coleryk man that is to seye a broune man that take the pulse in thin hande and if it meve fast aboue betwex the fell and flesche that is suall be the space of iij vnches to the pamewarde than leythe the malady aboue the mederefe and stoppeth the stomake
msItem.explicit: 85v so that the kynde suell that is to saye the hote agwe smyte not into the hede he is curable inowe and agayne the hote sekenes he most colde medycynes

msItem.title: Tract on nine sage leaves
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with a Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 85v De nouem folijs salgie
msItem.incipit: 85v [F]or to knowe the ix sauge leuys be the ix spires aforsayde whan the leuys be leyed in the myddes of the hand and hald therinne ij ourys or iij tyll they take odour of the pame of the hand and kyndely swete than it is token of lyfe and if the swetynge ouercome the odour of the sauge than the stomake and the hert stoppyd full of glete and engleymyd and that it a token of dethe etcaetera
msItem.note: Full transcription as in Mooney (1995), pp. 32-33.

msItem.title: Treatise on bloodletting
msItem.rubric: 86r To knowe the veynys of blodeletynge
msItem.incipit: 86r [T]he veyne in the myddes of the forhede is gode to blede on for the hede ache and mygryne that euyll taketh halfe the hede and maketh the hede to ake and also for the literge that maketh a man to foyette all that he heyreth
msItem.explicit: 88r for the bledder and for the genderynge membres for the palsye and for the euyll goute to lete blode on veynes of the feete lete hem be sette in water

msItem.title: Treatise on the influence of the planets on the human body
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with a Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 88r De iiiior qualitatibus quomodo diuidentur per influenciam planetarum
msItem.incipit: 88r Saturnus - [S]aturnus is colde and drye and whoso be born vnder this planete he schall be half folysche slowe and schrewednesse doynge malencolious in hert and euyll willynge hauynge scharp eres and thynne berde stynkyng clothes and vnclene and mowthe blake and he is of highe desire and his colour is blake
msItem.explicit: 88v luna is colde and moyste hoso is born vnder him . they be somwhate medelid with the other . and they be vnstable massangers and they be comyngly rennyng aboute he is rounde of euen stature and the oon eye is more than the other and selde it is seen \that/ oon of hem is withoute a wemme

msItem.title: Tract on the four complexions in the human body
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with a Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 88v De iiijor compleccionibus qui apparent in corporibus humanis
msItem.incipit: 88v-89r [T]he coleryke man hathe a broune face and somdele blake and broune or blake here and browne eyen a colerik man medelid with sangweyn hathe a browne face with rody chekes ffull of blode a colerik man medlid with malencolye hath a browne face and glessenynge pae and blake here comonly on his hede
msItem.explicit: 89r [T]he malencolye man is of ledy colour a malencolyk man medelid with white colour is a lede colouryd man . save he is somdele brown ther with . A malencolye man medled with flewme is a pale man and he is but schort of lyfe

msItem.title: Tract on the number of bones and teeth in the human body
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with a Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 89v De numero ossium et venarum ac dencium in humanis corporibus
msItem.incipit: 89v [T]her ben in a mannys body .ij. C. bones and xvij. And also ther ben in a mannes body iij. C. veynes and lxv . Also ther ben in a mannes hede that hathe perfyte ache xxxij tethe
msItem.explicit: 89v Vnderstandynge is yn the forhede / Mynde in the brayne / Wreth in the galle . / Auaryce in the stomake . loue in the herte . / Brethe and blode trust and feyte in the lunges . / Joye in the splene / thought in the body ./ hope in the soule ./ mynde in the spryte and feythe . /
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Note on ulcers
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with a Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 89v Nota de Cancro
msItem.incipit: 89v If it come oute of the flesche it cometh oute as thikke wose and if it come oute of the senowes it comythe out \as/ lye and if it be in the bone than it cometh oute as blode and vnderstand that the wolffe \comethe/ comonlye in the theyes or in the feete but that that is curable schewith .iij. thinges . grete stenche . grete fretynge . and the wounde waxeth blake.
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: A Noble tretis for Medicina Agenst the Pestilence [from the shorter version of De Pestilencia]
msItem.author: John of Burgundy
msItem.incipit: 90r [H]ere begynnyth a nobylle tretyse made of a phesicyan John of Burdewes . ffor medycynes ayeyne pestelense euylles and it is departid in .iiij partys
msItem.explicit: 92r Whoso is ther inne . blede betyme as the other capitle tellyth and rewle him after the .iij. and throwe the grace of god he schall scape this sekenesse and be dylyueryd ther fro

msItem.title: Treatment for the plague
msItem.textLang: Latin text with Middle English plant names
msItem.incipit: 92r Vnum remedium reseruatiuum inter alia inserere . videlicet quod fugiiendum esset a loco ubi regna mortalitas ad alium locum in quo non habet sedem
msItem.explicit: 92r Aque solsequij . solatry . pympernoll . ffumiterre . scabiose . rose . herbe johannis . Amarusse ance Maythe . ed [sic] endiue agrestes ance sowthistill . acedule . ance sorell

msItem.title: Biblical verses on the Trinity
msItem.incipit: 92r + Pater est Alpha et oo + ihesus Christus passus est pro nobis. / + ffilius est vita + ou pro nobis obediens . / + Spiritus sanctus est remedium + ihesus vsque ad mortem.
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by a different 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Recipe for an oral anaesthetic
msItem.rubric: 92v To make a drynke that men clepe dwale to make a man to slepe whil he is coruen

msItem.title: Three medical recipes for treating eye ailments
Tract on ten medicinal waters
msItem.rubric: 93r [H]ere begynnyth distillynge of waterys and her uertues for certayne sekenys . Water of Rosis . Water of beteyn . Water of borage . Water of fenell . Water of euf\r/ase . Water of floures of elder . Water of mugwede . Water of sawge . Water of ysope . Water of fumytere . Water of scabyous . Water of wortes.
msItem.incipit: 93r Watter of rosis - Is gode for all scharpe feueres dronkyn with wyne or ale and it bryngeth a man in gode temper if he a noynte him selfe with oute at the templis and in other dyuerse places.
msItem.explicit: 93v Water of cowles - drinken with wyne or ale .vj. sponfull as thus .iiij. sponfull of wyne or ale . and ij. sponfull of the forsayde water with a noyntyng with out aboute the face and the temples and take of all these forsayd wateres and medle hem to geder and it is best water in the werdle to wasche stynkyng woundes

msItem.title: Recipe for a medicinal water to treat blindness
msItem.rubric: 93v A precyous water for eyn that loke fayre and clere and be blynde
msItem.incipit: 93v Take smallache . rede fenell . rewe . verueyn . egrimoyn . quinfoyle . pympernoll . eufrase . sauge . celydoyn of eche a quartorn . wassche hem clene and stampe hem and do hem in a fayre brasse panne and take the pouder of .xv. peper cornes fayre sarced . and a pynte of gode white wyne do to the herbes . and iij. sponfull of hony and .v. sponfull of a knave childes vryne that is an innocente and medle hem wele to geder and than lete boyle hem a lytyll ouer the fyer and streyne hem throwe a clene clothe and do it in to a vessell of glasse and stopp it till thu wilte ocupye it . and with a feder put it in to the sore eyen . and if it drye temper it with white wyne . this water is gode for all maner vyces of the eyn and it will make a man to se ryght wele with inne .ix. dayes probatum est.
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Four medical recipes
msItem.note: Added by a later 15th- or 16th-century hand. The same hand has added further recipes to f. 103v.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treating a kidney stone
msItem.rubric: 94v ffor the Stone
msItem.note: Added by a later 15th- or 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treating jaundice
msItem.rubric: 95r ffor the yelow chaundyse
msItem.note: Added by a 16th-century hand and attributed to or signed by Magister R. Arche anno domini 1548.

msItem.title: Saying (incomplete)
msItem.incipit: 95v Dum sumus in mundo vyva - Dum sumus
msItem.note: Incomplete version of the saying: Dum sumus in mundo, vivamus corde jocundo. Added by a later 15th- or early 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: The Alchemical Waters of St Giles
msItem.rubric: 96r The ix wateres of seynte gyle
msItem.incipit: 96r Here begynnyth the makynge of wateres of seynte gyle compyled be phelosiphers the waters of philysophres schall be made in this wyse
msItem.explicit: 98v And vnderstand wele that alle these for sayde wateres after her furst distillacyon . excepte aqua dealbativa . in porcyon sode with castorye rubarbe and sugre onto the .iij. parte be consumyd werketh mervously in dyuerse infirmytees.
msItem.finalRubric: 98v Explicit the ix wateres of seynte Gyle

msItem.title: Medical treatment for curing St Eligius's evil
msItem.rubric: 98v ffor toe cure the euylles of seynte loy
msItem.incipit: 98v Take a quantyte of iche of the .ix. wateres a forsayde and of iche lyche moche and medle hem to geder all in a glasse and ij on the day wassche the sore therwith and take a tente or a lytyll lynett and wete it in this water and put it in the buttome of the sore
msItem.explicit: 99r And who so euer maye not be cured with this water he schall neuer be cured for no medycine that ony man can make.
msItem.note: St Eligius's evil refers to an ulcer, wound or fistula that takes a long time to heal (see Mooney (1995), p. 35 for further references).

msItem.title: Collection of eight recipes for medicinal waters
Collection of sixteen recipes for making medicinal oils
msItem.incipit: 100v [H]ere begynnythe the makynge of oyles of diuerse herbys for dyuerse infirmytees and furst we schall declare the makynge of oyle of laurus and procede
msItem.explicit: 103r Oyle of almundes and of other kyrnellys - Take almundes and blaunche hem and put hem in a pott and sett it on an other sethyng potte and the breth of that sething potte schall ryse and enter into the kyrnelles and that is gode whan it is wrong throw a clothe

msItem.title: Collection of four medical recipes
msItem.note: Added by a later 15th- or 16th-century hand. The same hand has added further recipes to ff. 93r-93v.

msItem.title: Collection of recipes for making medicinal salves and ointments
msItem.rubric: 104r [H]ere begynnyth the makynge of entretis and oynementes for all maner woundes and sores
msItem.note: Contains 46 medical recipes. The final recipe (ffor horssnesse) may have been added later by the main hand or a different hand.

msItem.title: Treatise on gathering herbs for making medicines
msItem.incipit: 113r [M]edycynes be doon som be leuys be ȝerdes \and sum be rootes/ sum be flowres sum be seedes/ and sum be frutes whan leues go to medycynes they schall be gadred whan they be at her waxyng or that her colour chaungyth and or that they yelow or fade ony thing
msItem.explicit: 114v The seed of silermonteyn serueth for medycynes . The rote of saxifrage is vsid in medycynes . Scabyous while he is grene he is of uertu and elles not

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.rubric: 116r Here begynnythe gode medicines for diuerse infirmytees of mannes body / And furst we schalle begynne at the hede and after of other
msItem.note: Contains 124 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Herbal (begininng)
msItem.incipit: 128r Aloe is hote and drye in the .ij. degre and it is made of the iuse of an herbe that is callid aloe and that herbe is founde in ynde in perse in grece and in appuleye
msItem.explicit: 129v And the help is thus lette him drynke grete quantyte of gotes mylk and lete him be mevyng and steryng or lete him drynke the wyne that ysope and wormod be soden inn
msItem.note: The herbal only contains entries for herbs starting with the letter A: aloe, aloes, azafetida, and argentum.
Contains extracts from the Circa instans.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.rubric: 129v ffor the Scabbe

msItem.title: Instructions for grafting fruit trees, nut trees, and roses [extracted from the Middle English version of the Book of Trees and Wine]
msItem.author: Geoffrey of Vinsauf
msItem.incipit: 130r If ye will graffe a tree qwich frute schall haue no corys. Take a graffe and bowe it yn both endes cranyng and both endes with a knyfe and fastyn so both endes in the stokke and yf it growe so with the tree kutt away the gretter and suffer the smaller ende growe still
msItem.explicit: 130v Also take many rype wallnottes the which yf they be a while watered and put in a moyst pitt and helled with erth . ther schall growe therof a stoke ryght grete that we call maser in duchelond.

msItem.title: Craft of Grafting (extract)
msItem.author: Nicholas Bollard
msItem.incipit: 131r Nowe it is to witt that when the mone is in tauro it is gode tyme to plant trees of graynes and pepynes
msItem.explicit: 131r Of disposicyoun of the place and of a rayng of erth . In euery plantyng it is to dispose so that the sunne bemys com to the rote or to the erth fro the terce hour till it be noon and thenn be they plantyd in the best maner etcaetera

msItem.title: Charm to staunch blood
msItem.rubric: 132r A charme to staunche blood
msItem.incipit: 132r Longius miles latus saluatoris aparuit et continuo exiuit sanguis et aqua sanguis redempcionis et aqua baptismatus in nomine patris + cesset sanguis in nomine filii + restat sanguis in nomine spiritus sancti + non exeat sanguis amplius de ore vel de naso vel de vena and name this charm .iiij. tymes with iij. pater nosters and .iij Aues.
msItem.note: The charm has been crossed out.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Contains 18 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for use on teeth
msItem.note: Contains nine recipes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Contains seven medical recipes.

msItem.title: Charm Pro spasmo
msItem.rubric: 134r Pro spasmo
msItem.incipit: 134r Bake bake ybake girte gute hany ga gu greton grab et sibra vriel tobiel
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by a later 15th- or 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Of herbs twenty-three
msItem.incipit: 134v [A]strologye ther been of hem too / the longe and the round also
msItem.explicit: 146v Ne the deuyl schall him do slone / Nor tempest of weder schall him greve none
msItem.note: In the lower margin of f. 134v, a different 15th-century hand has added a reference to the continuation of the poem on f. 144v: Quere plus ad tale signum :+:.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes and treatments for a variety of ailments and illnesses
msItem.note: One of female healthcare recipes (f. 141r) contains a word encoded in cypher: Item si mulier pertet cor tbmbnboesf [decoded: salamandre] in curibus suis non concipiet aliquo modo.
A later (?) 16th-century hand has added translations into English for all of the Latin titles for the recipes in this collection.

msItem.title: Moral poem
msItem.incipit: 140r ffeare gode and the kinge / be lothe for to offend / take notinge in hand
msItem.note: Copied by the same 16th-century hand that added a draft line, possilby from Job 9:29, to f. 52r and the first line of the poem that has been abbreviated here and has been copied in full by a different 16th-century hand on f. 54v.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for St Anthony's Fire
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand. A 16th-century hand has translated the recipe's title into English: ffor the fyre off seynte Antonye.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treating eachache
msItem.rubric: 144r ffor þe aking of þe Eere
msItem.note: Added by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treatment of earache
msItem.note: Added in the late 15th or 16th century.

msItem.title: Poem on the Virtues of Herbs, especially Rosemary
msItem.incipit: 147r [T]ake the floures of Rosemary / And bynde hem in a lynnyne cloth clenly
msItem.explicit: 148r Thes be the vertues of Rosmary / As we haue of olde techers and leches trewly / of Saryseynys of Iues of englysch bokes worthy / wele preuyd and Iugyd sothe and Iustly
msItem.finalRubric: 148r fflores eius manduca per iii dies et illo Anno noli me tangere / nec lepra nec alia Apostomata habebis . etcaetera

msItem.title: Three medical recipes
msItem.note: Two of the recipes are Pro Anelitu Fetido.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for the collicke and the stone
msItem.note: Added by a 16th-century hand; another later (? 18th-century) hand copied this recipe on f. 149r.

msItem.title: Proverb on studying (incomplete) from Peter Idley's Instructions to His Son with reference to John Cheak
msItem.author: Peter Idley
msItem.incipit: 149r I haue harde saie in olde romanse he that in youthe will do his diligens to learne in age - ffor that John Cheak
msItem.note: Added by a 16th-century hand.

Incomplete version of the proverb: I have heard said in old Romance / He that in youth will do his diligence / To learn, in age it will him advance / To keep him from all indigence. (see Peter Idley's Instructions to His Son, ed. by C. D'Evelyn (Boston: Heath, 1935), p. 81) with reference to John Cheak, who may be Sir John Cheke (1514-1557), humanist, administrator, royal tutor, and regius professor at Cambridge.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for the Clollicke [sic] and Stone
msItem.note: An (?) 18th-century copy of the 16th-century recipe onto f. 148v.

msItem.title: List of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 150r playster of diaslesmas in pixide howelln fulin colores simile a postalicion quod est nigri colores / Item Emplastrum Jacob rubei coloris / Item vnguentum frigidum which lokyth whyt lyk mayes butter in pixide howell
msItem.note: Added to the base of a blank page by a 15th- or 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of five medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes have been copied by two different 15th-century hands.

supportDesc.support: Parchment (ff. 1-66b) and Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 67r-150v: Bull's head with cross.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and line ruling. Single columns. 26 lines to the page, written above top line.
Ruled in hardpoint, frame and line ruling. Single columns. 27 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: Folios 1r-148v were largely copied by one hand working in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 76r-80v were copied by a hand working in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Various recipes added throughout by hands working in cursive scripts with anglicana or secretary features or combinations of both.

decoNote.p: A large (2 lines) plain red initial (C) has been added to one of the many spaces that have been left blank for decorated initials on f. 70r.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.32, ff. 151-173

msItem.title: Tractatus de simplicibus medicinis [Circa instans[
msItem.author: Matthaeus Platearius
msItem.incipit: 151r Circa instans negocium in medicinis simplicibus
msItem.explicit: 168r puluere camphere
msItem.note: Ends abruptly in the section on Cerusa.

msItem.title: Pangram
msItem.incipit: 168v Equore congelido zephyrus fert xennia kymbus
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note: The recipe refers to modum leche lumbardum.

msItem.title: Unidentified theological extracts
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand. The text has become much faded and is poorly legible. It includes the following statements: non est castitas, non est fides, and hic non est lex neque laus. On f. 169r, a new extract begins with the heading: Spes.

msItem.title: (?) Saying
msItem.incipit: 169r Notandum est quod sicut placuit dominus ita fiat
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Verse saying about women
msItem.incipit: 169v Est species morbi mulierem tangere noli / Si tangis tangit si tangit sedere nescit / Ergo fuge tactum ne res procedat in actum
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has copied all but one of the verse sayings on ff. 169v-170r.

msItem.title: Verse saying
msItem.incipit: 169v Colloquium visus contractus et osscula risus / Sunt fomes veneris hec fuge saluus eris
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has copied all but one of the verse sayings on ff. 169v-170r.

msItem.title: Verse saying about women
msItem.incipit: 169v Generi qui gaudes meretricem qualiter aude / Membris [not transcribed]
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has copied all but one of the verse sayings on ff. 169v-170r.

msItem.title: Verse saying
msItem.incipit: 169v Arbor inest silvis quae scribitur octo figuris / Inde tribus demptis vix vna mille videbis
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has copied all but one of the verse sayings on ff. 169v-170r.

msItem.title: Verse saying about women
msItem.incipit: 169v Poma mericas edere dicas melque sicutas / Cum mulieres dicere speres res tibi tutas
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has copied all but one of the verse sayings on ff. 169v-170r.

msItem.title: Verse saying about women
msItem.incipit: 169v Omnis revera meretrix est dicta chymera / Parte leo prima medio capra anguis in yma / Est leo per fastum capra ydrus ad astum "
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has copied all but one of the verse sayings on ff. 169v-170r.

msItem.title: Verse saying about women
msItem.incipit: 169v Admodum sampsonem sic david sic salamonem / femina decepit quis modo tutus erit
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has copied all but one of the verse sayings on ff. 169v-170r.

msItem.title: Verse saying about women
msItem.incipit: 169v Cum deceptus eris mulieri si socieris [2nd and 3rd lines not transcribed]
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has copied all but one of the verse sayings on ff. 169v-170r.

msItem.title: Verse saying about women
msItem.incipit: 170r Nemo potest fari vel cernere vel medi[tare] / Si dicat verum quot fraudes sunt mulierum
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has copied all but one of the verse sayings on ff. 169v-170r.

msItem.title: Verse saying about women
msItem.incipit: 170r Si membrana foret polus encaustum mare . stelle non possunt penne mulierum scribere velle
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has copied all but one of the verse sayings on ff. 169v-170r.

msItem.title: Verse saying about women
msItem.incipit: 170r Nemo potest vel fari vel cernere vel meditare / Si dicat verum quot fraudes sunt mulierem
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand, copying the first verse saying at the top of the page, different from the hand that has added the previous verse sayings to ff. 169v-170r.

msItem.title: Accounts
msItem.note: Added in the 15th century. Many of the notes have been crossed out. The notes apparently concern payments for wax (cera), including persons such as elizabeth colyns, William Smyth, Edward ?Dier, William Edward, John Smyth, Stephen ?Whyt[...], William Adeler, Robert ?Magot, Thomas Taylour, Milward ?Cornyssdon, Stephani Milward, Anneys colyns, William ?Maleham, Thomas Sampson, William Seward, John ?Vaire, ?Aubert MannyngJohn ?Stangle, William Baker, Thomas Towker, Ricard Martyn, Richard ȝerward, Thomas Gybbe. The date 1427 (Anno domini Millesimo CCCC xxvijo intrante) is written at the top of f. 172r in the hand that has written the accounts.

msItem.title: Verse saying about women
msItem.incipit: 171r Tu deceptus eris mulieris si socieris / Si sponsum queris sepe molestus erit / Raro ridebis raro sine lite iacebis
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Verse saying about women
msItem.incipit: 171r Adam Sampsonem sic dauid sic salomonem / ffemina decepit quis modo tutus erit
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Saying about strife at Oxford as a sign for war in England
msItem.incipit: 171v Si cronicas penses : bellunt Oxonienses / post paucos menses bellabunt Angliginenses [sic]
msItem.note: Another version of this saying reads: Chronica si penses, cum pugnant Oxonienses, Post paucos menses, volat ira per Angligenenses..
Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Matthew 16:13-24
msItem.rubric: 171v Vade post me Sathana
msItem.incipit: 171v Mathaeus xvjo in euangelium venit autem ihesus in partes cesaree philippi et interogauit discipulos dicens quem dicunt homines esse flium hominis
msItem.explicit: 171v Et dixit: Si quis vult post me venire abneget semetipsum et tollat crucem suam et sequatur
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Recipe
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand. The text is much faded. Probably a medical recipe but its purpose has not been established.

msItem.title: Astronomical notes
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand. The notes appear to refer to dominical letters (A-G).

msItem.title: Unidentified religious text
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand. The text is difficult to read due to fading and damage to the page.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 151-171: antlers.
supportDesc.condition: The lower outer corners of folios 169 and 171 are torn off, and folios 170, 172, and 173 are fragmentary leaves.

p.seg: Ruled in hardpoint, frame only (but only rarely visible). Single columns. 35-41 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Folios 151r-168r have been copied by a single cursive hand in a script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Folios 168v-173v have additions by various hands in scripts with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant forms of decoration.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries
